title: Quiz 5: Cultural Competence & Community Roles
description: Evaluate your understanding of Community Health Workers (CHWs) and the importance of cultural competence in mental health.

questions.question: What is the definition of Cultural Competence in mental health?

options.text: Understanding and respecting cultural differences in health experiences
Ignoring culture to treat everyone exactly the same
Only treating patients from your own culture

questions.explanation: Cultural competence involves understanding, respecting, and responding appropriately to cultural differences.

questions.question: What are key functions of Community Health Workers (CHWs) in mental health? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: CHWs educate, support, refer, advocate, and build trust. They do not perform surgery.

questions.question: Match the Cultural Factor to its impact on mental health:

pairs.right: Family involvement in treatment is crucial
May view illness as a sign of weakness/failure
May seek guidance from religious leaders

questions.explanation: Collectivism values the group; Stigma causes shame; Communication dictates how feelings are shown; Spirituality involves religion.
questions.hint: Connect the cultural concept to the behavior it drives.

questions.question: ___BLANK___ involves approaching each individual with an open mind, willingness to learn, and deep respect for their culture, rather than assuming expertise.
questions.explanation: Cultural Humility is the ongoing process of self-reflection and learning about others' cultures.
questions.hint: It is the opposite of cultural arrogance.

questions.question: Using family members as interpreters is always better than using professional translators in mental health settings.
questions.explanation: Professional interpreters are preferred to ensure accuracy and confidentiality; family members may filter information or lack medical vocabulary.

questions.question: Which strategy helps reduce mental health stigma in diverse communities?

richContent.content: Goal: Normalizing conversations and challenging misconceptions.

options.text: Engaging community leaders and religious figures

questions.explanation: Engaging trusted community leaders helps validate mental health importance and reduces stigma culturally.
questions.hint: Who do people trust in their communities?

questions.question: What is the term for a community worker who serves as a liaison between health services and the community?
questions.explanation: A Community Health Worker (CHW) bridges the gap between the community and formal health systems.

questions.question: Rank the steps for developing a Culturally Competent Approach:

items.text: Gain knowledge of community cultural backgrounds

questions.explanation: First understand (knowledge), then partner (collaborate), then assess tools, and finally deliver the intervention.

questions.question: In some cultures, mental health symptoms may be expressed as physical ailments (e.g., headaches). What is this called?
questions.explanation: Somatization is the expression of psychological distress through physical symptoms, common in many Asian and other cultures.
questions.hint: It relates to the 'soma' or body.

questions.question: CHWs break down barriers of distrust towards formal health services.
questions.explanation: As trusted community members, CHWs help bridge the gap of trust between the community and the healthcare system.
questions.hint: Are CHWs usually trusted by their own community?
